record.attribute:
FungiDB belongs to the EuPathDB family of databases and is an integrated genomic and functional genomic database for the kingdom Fungi. FungiDB was first released in early 2011 as a collaborative project between EuPathDB and the group of Jason Stajich (University of California, Riverside). At the end of 2015, FungiDB was integrated into the EuPathDB bioinformatic resource center - see this news item for additional information. For a list of the data integrated into FungiDB today and the related publications please see Data Sets.

FungiDB integrates whole genome sequence and annotation and also includes experimental and environmental isolate sequence data. The database includes comparative genomics, analysis of gene expression, and supplemental bioinformatics analyses and a web interface for data-mining.

Please check our annual EuPathDB Workshop at UGA exercises to see the scope of data and functionality in our sites.

Much of the data in FungiDB is provided by independent researchers. For a list of the data integrated into FungiDB and the related publications see Data Sets. Please cite the authors/providers when you use their data.

FungiDB scientific advisory groups (list will be updated as additional groups are formed and advisors added):
EuPathDB has been working closely with AspGD to ensure a smooth transition of data to FungiDB - see this letter to the Aspergillus community for additional details.


Currently we have the following teams:

The Aspregillus scientific advisory group:

  • Mikael Rørdam Andersen (Technical University of Denmark, Denmark)
  • Elaine Bignell (The University of Manchester, UK)
  • Michelle Momany (University of Georgia, USA)
  • Antonis Rokas (Vanderbilt University, USA)


The Neurospora scientific advisory group:

  • Jay Dunlap (Darmouth)
  • Louise Glass (University of California, Berkley, USA)
  • Katherine Borkovich (University of California, Riverside, USA)
  • Jason Stajich (University of California, Riverside, USA)


The Fusarium scientific advisory group:

  • Michael Freitag (Oregon State University, USA)
  • Corby Kistler (University of Minnesota, USA)
  • Nadya Ponts (INRA, France)
  • Kim Hammond-Kosack (Rothamsted, UK)
  • Seogchan Kang (The Pennsylvania State University, USA)
  • Christina Cuomo (The Broad Institute, USA)


The Coccidioides scientific advisory group:

  • Bridget Barker (North Arizona University, USA)
  • Theo Kirkland (University of California, San Diego, USA)
  • Marc Orbach (University of Arizona, USA)


The Cryptococcus scientific advisory group:

  • Tamara Doering (Washington University in St. Louis, USA)
  • Jennifer Lodge (Washington University in St. Louis, USA)
  • Robin May (University of Birmingham, UK)
  • Guilhem Janbon (Institut Pasteur, France)
  • Christina Cuomo (The Broad Institute, USA)

FungiDB is a member of pathogen-databases that are housed under the NIAID-funded EuPathDB Bioinformatics Resource Center (BRC) umbrella. FungiDB was initially funded through a grant from the Burroughs Wellcome Fund grant to Jason Stajich (UC Riverside, USA) and David Roos (University of Pennsylvania, USA and EuPathDB). Currently the database is supported by the NIAID grant and a grant from The Wellcome Trust grant to Christiane Hertz-Fowler (University of Liverpool, United Kingdom) and David Roos (University of Pennsylvania, USA). The EuPathDB team is mainly distributed between the University of Pennsylvania Philadelphia, USA the University of Georgia, Georgia, USA, and several members of the team are located at the University of Liverpool, United Kingdom, University of Glasgow, United Kingdom and The Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute, United Kingdom.

The data at this site is provided freely for public use, through the contributions of many researchers including those involved in generating the genome sequences. The data is not guaranteed to be accurate as it often reflects the results of ongoing research. When using data obtained from FungiDB or an EuPathDB project, it is important to cite the original publications and contributors of that data.
Please see Citing FungiDB below.

We do not use or share any of your personal information for any purpose unrelated to the functionality of the websites; however, we do collect some information to help us understand how our sites are being used and to improve community support. See the Website Privacy Policy for details.

When citing FungiDB itself, please use:

FungiDB: an integrated functional genomics database for fungi.
2012 Nucleic Acids Res. Jan 4;40(D1):D675-D681. doi: 10.1093/nar/gkr918
[ Full text ]

When citing EuPathDB itself, please use:
EuPathDB: the eukaryotic pathogen genomics database resource.
2017 Nucleic Acids Res. Jan 4;45(D1):D581-D591. doi: 10.1093/nar/gkw1105
[ Full text ]

Much of the data in FungiDB is provided by independent researchers. Please cite them if you use their data. For a list of the data integrated into FungiDB and the related publications please see Data Sets.
